src:
Sánchez rectifica sobre la Fiscalia: "És autònoma. Ahir no vaig ser gaire precís"
El president del govern en funcions ha assegurat que respecta el poder judicial

07 Nov 2019, 11:51

El president del govern espanyol en funcions, Pedro Sánchez, ha admès que va cometre un error quan va afirmar aquest dimecres que el seu executiu controlava la Fiscalia i que no va ser “gaire precís” durant l’entrevista ahir a RNE. "Són moltes hores" durant la campanya, s'ha excusat. En una nova entrevista a La Sexta aquest dijous, Sánchez ha subratllat que el nomenament de la Fiscalia depèn del govern central “però és autònoma” i "té independència". El líder del PSOE ha assegurat que ell “sempre ha respectat el poder judicial” i que l’únic que volia dir és que “no hi ha ningú per sobre de la llei”.
Pedro Sánchez també ha fet marxa enrere en el seu compromís durant el debat electoral de portar Puigdemont a Espanya perquè sigui jutjat. "Són expressions que s'utilitzen als debats", s'ha justificat. "El compromís del govern d'Espanya és que les sentències es compleixin", ha assegurat. "El nostre paper és ajudar la Fiscalia i el poder judicial a fer que es compleixin les sentències", ha insistit. 
El president del govern espanyol en funcions no ha revelat si la rectificació del sistema Sirene –el que gestiona les euroordres– de la paraula desproporcionada per referir-se a l'euroordre de l'exconsellera Clara Ponsatí responia a pressions diplomàtiques i s'ha limitat a dir que l'únic que ha fet la policia britànica és demanar més informació sobre la sentència del Procés. "Hem rebut les disculpes de l'ambaixador", ha dit Sánchez. 
Compareixença de Torra
El líder del PSOE també ha qualificat de "greu" la informació que apunta que els CDR detinguts haurien preparat presumptament l'ocupació del Parlament de Catalunya amb el vistiplau del president de la Generalitat, Quim Torra. "El que ha de fer Torra és comparèixer al Parlament i explicar si dona veracitat a aquestes informacions", ha demanat Pedro Sánchez.
text:
Sánchez corrects on the Public Prosecutor's Office: "It is autonomous. Yesterday I was not very precise"
The acting president has assured that the judiciary is respected

07 Nov 2019, 11:51

The Spanish government's president, Pedro Sánchez, admitted that he made a mistake when he said Wednesday that his executive was in charge of the Prosecutor's Office and that it was not "very accurate" during the interview yesterday at RNE. "It's a lot of hours" during the campaign, it's been excused. In a new interview with La Sexta this Thursday, Sánchez emphasized that the appointment of the Prosecutor's Office depends on the central government "but it is autonomous" and "has independence". The leader of the PSOE assured that he "has always respected the judiciary" and that the only thing he wanted to say is that "there is no one above the law."
Pedro Sánchez also has gone back in his commitment during the electoral debate to bring Puigdemont to Spain to be judged. "They are expressions that are used in debates," it has been justified. "The commitment of the government of Spain is that the sentences are complied with", he assured. "Our role is to help the Prosecutor's Office and the judiciary to enforce the sentences," he insisted.
The president of the Spanish government in office has not revealed whether rectification of the Sirene system, which manages the euroorders, of the disproportionate word to refer to the euroorder of the consellery Clara Ponsatí responded to diplomatic pressures and was limited To say that the only thing that the British police have done is to ask for more information about the ruling of the Process. "We have received the apologies of the ambassador," said Sánchez.
Look for Torra
The leader of the PSOE has also described as "serious" the information that suggests that the detained CDRs would have presumably prepared the employment of the Parliament of Catalonia with the approval of the president of the Generalitat, Quim Torra. "What must be done by Torra is to appear in Parliament and explain if he gives truth to these information," asked Pedro Sánchez.
